title: Fluid-rock Interaction in Near-surface environments: Thermodynamics and Kinetics
description: Fluid-rock interaction represents one of the unique phenomena on the surface/subsurface of Earth, where the chemical compositions of Earth's crust are modified by fluid (mostly water) over geological times. The electrolytes in the solution as a result of the interaction are strongly related to the global carbon cycle and are important sources of chemical input to the ocean. The interaction has recently been applied to meet societal needs, including toxic radioactive water treatment and storage, and geological sequestration and storage of anthropogenic CO2 in mafic/ultramafic rocks and rock formations. In this class, we read a set of review papers to become familiar with principles of thermodynamic and kinetic models used to describe/simulate the chemical reactions; discuss the applications of the models to geological problems; and learn commercially available software (e.g., EQ 3/6) to solve problems. This is a reading and presentation class. In the beginning, lectures introduce fundamentals, but thereafter, students lead discussions and make presentations. A group project is assigned.
